isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - LIFT AXLE SYSTEMS - FIXED (RIGID) AXLE ASSEMBLIES - ADJUSTMENTS

svcsubproc.title: AXLE ALIGNMENT
svcsubproc.para: Axle alignment is necessary only after major mechanical repairs or bushing replacement; or if uneven tire wear is noticed. This procedure is for alignment of axles with eccentric collars.

step1.para: Verify that the tires on the axle assembly being aligned are the same size, diameter, and inflation pressure.
Park the truck so that the truck and axle are level.
Measure the frame-to-ground clearance on both sides of the truck frame. Refer to FIGURE 11. The dimensions must be the same (± 1/8 inch) to align properly.
Start out with the adjustment square cutout (on all four concentric collars) vertically aligned with the pivot bolt, as shown in FIGURE 12 .
Snug up one side so that the collars on that pivot cannot rotate.

Using a 1/2 inch break over bar or ratchet, rotate the two collars on the other hanger (the side being adjusted) so that the suspension moves forward or backward to allow the distance from center of spindle to the center of the drive axle (dimensions C and D) to be equal distance ±1/8 inch. Refer to FIGURE 13 . If more suspension movement is needed for alignment, loosen the pivot bolt securing the centered collars on the unadjusted hanger, and rotate the collars to allow for more movement.
Snug up the pivot bolt, on the side being adjusted, so that the collars cannot rotate
Tighten both of the pivot bolts to a torque value of 850 lbf-ft.
